head.title: Not All Scientists Back Global Warming Treaty

hedline.hl1: Not All Scientists Back Global Warming Treaty

abstract.p: Letter by H Sterling Burnett of National Center for Policy Analysis comments on June 22 editorial on global warming; notes lack of consensus among scientists who worked on United Nations report for global warming treaty (S)

block.p: ''No Hot Air on Global Warming'' (editorial, June 22) overlooks several important points regarding the global treaties on climate change. As you say, some 2,500 scientists worked on the report of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, but far fewer than that number agreed with its findings. Polling done by Greenpeace and Gallup shows that climatologists reject by a wide margin the notion that humans are causing cataclysmic global warming.

''No Hot Air on Global Warming'' (editorial, June 22) overlooks several important points regarding the global treaties on climate change. As you say, some 2,500 scientists worked on the report of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, but far fewer than that number agreed with its findings. Polling done by Greenpeace and Gallup shows that climatologists reject by a wide margin the notion that humans are causing cataclysmic global warming.

As for economics, of the more than 21,000 members of the American Economic Association who were asked to sign the statement concerning the benefits of the treaties, only 2,400 did. That hardly amounts to a consensus. Indeed, 24 major studies of the potential cost of the treaties have been done, and all indicate that the proposals would cause severe economic harm.
Environmental Policy Analyst Natl. Center for Policy Analysis
